plants.name: Crocus vernus
plants.description: A perennial bulbous plant known for signaling the start of spring with its cup-shaped flowers that emerge through late winter snow in temperate regions.
plants.location: Native to central and southern Europe, widely cultivated in temperate gardens worldwide
plants.funFact: Crocuses were among the first flowers cultivated by ancient humans and have been used historically as a source of saffron from a related species.

plants.name: Rhododendron ferrugineum
plants.description: An evergreen shrub that thrives in acidic, alpine soils and produces bright pink to red bell-shaped flowers during late winter to early spring in mountainous regions.
plants.location: Alps and Pyrenees mountain ranges of Europe
plants.funFact: The Alpenrose is the floral emblem of the Swiss canton of Valais, symbolizing the beauty and resilience of alpine flora.

plants.name: Acacia dealbata
plants.description: A fast-growing evergreen tree famous for its fluffy, fragrant yellow flower clusters that brighten late winter landscapes in Mediterranean and subtropical climates.
plants.location: Native to southeastern Australia; widely planted in Mediterranean, California, and southern Europe climates
plants.funFact: The Silver Wattle is celebrated in parts of Europe, such as Italy and France, where its blooming is associated with international womenâ€™s day in early March.

plants.name: Camellia japonica
plants.description: An evergreen shrub or small tree with glossy leaves and large, showy flowers blooming in winter to early spring, popular in shaded garden areas of temperate regions.
plants.location: Native to Japan, Korea, and China; widely cultivated in temperate gardens worldwide
plants.funFact: Camellia flowers were historically prized in East Asia not only as ornamental plants but also as symbols of purity and longevity.
